The date of the glacier collapse warning in Switzerland, demonstrating real-time application of early warning systems to save lives and infrastructure.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current year, marked by an escalating number of extreme weather events globally, reinforcing urgency for improved early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, increasing vulnerability, especially in developing nations.
The WMO reports that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early warnings, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate hazards in the past 50 years, primarily in vulnerable regions.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems—up from 52—62 countries still have only basic or less-than-basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected areas and developing nations.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functional early warning websites and standardized alerts.
Early warnings enable early action, and the WMO aims to empower communities and nations to respond proactively.
Recent extreme weather events in 2025—such as flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US—highlight the global scale of the crisis.
Switzerland’s early detection of a mountain glacier collapse in May 2025 allowed evacuation of the village of Blatten, proving the life-saving potential of monitoring and alerts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a global call to strengthen early-warning systems for extreme weather, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting. The WMO highlights that over 2 million people have died from weather-related disasters in the past 50 years, with 90% of these deaths in developing nations. Despite progress in early warning adoption—rising from 52 to 108 countries—the assessment reveals that 50% of surveyed countries have only basic capacity, and 16% have less than basic. The article emphasizes real-world examples, such as the evacuation of Switzerland’s Blatten village due to a glacier collapse in May 2025, and widespread disasters in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, southern Europe, and the United States in 2025. The WMO stresses that early warnings enable early action and is vital to saving lives, protecting infrastructure, and addressing the spiraling impact of climate change.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
